map_node.indicator_name: Asthma triggers: Adults reporting secondhand smoke at home
map_node.indicator_description: Secondhand smoke, especially indoors, is bad for health - especially for the health of children.

dataset.how_calculated:
Estimated number of adults in an area exposed to second-hand smoke at home, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.

 

Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time in their homes are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at home.
dataset.discription: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

dataset.how_calculated:
Estimated number of adults exposed to second-hand smoke at home, rounded to the nearest 1,000.

 

Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time in their homes are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at home.
dataset.discription: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

unreliable_text: * Estimate is based on small numbers so should be interpreted with caution.
** Estimate is suppressed due to insufficient data.

show_disparities_node.disparitiesPagetext: When population health or the quality of living environments varies by population characteristics such as income or race, there is disparity. One way to visualize disparity is to chart indicators of health or environment across levels of neighborhood poverty. We categorized neighborhoods as high, medium or low poverty. Then we took the median of the neighborhood-specific values in each category. The median is the middle of the sorted group of values.
show_disparities_node.indicator_name: Asthma triggers: Adults reporting secondhand smoke at home

info.info_how_calculated:
Estimated number of adults in an area exposed to second-hand smoke at home, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.

 

Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time in their homes are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at home.
info.info_source: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

info.info_name: Neighborhood Poverty
info.info_how_calculated: Neighborhoods are ranked according to the percent of people whose annual income falls below 100% of the federal poverty level. Rankings are then divided into 3 approximately equal groupings of low, medium and high poverty.
info.info_source: American Community Survey

link_data_node.linkDataPagetext: The "Link Data" function shows associations between environmental health data at the neighborhood level using <a href="http://a816-dohbesp.nyc.gov/IndicatorPublic/Glossary.aspx?#Scatterplot" target="_blank">scatterplots.</a> The points represent x and y values for each NYC neighborhood. The pairs of indicators available for scatterplots were chosen because previous research suggests that one may either directly or indirectly cause or contribute to the other. Because the data being charted are <a href="http://a816-dohbesp.nyc.gov/IndicatorPublic/Glossary.aspx?#Ecological_Study" target="_blank">ecological</a> and not individual level, and because many factors contribute to the health of a population or environment, the patterns seen in these charts do not necessarily represent the underlying causal relationship.
link_data_node.indicator_name: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home

Compare.x_axis_title: Public School Children (5-14 Yrs Old) with Asthma - Estimated Annual Rate (per 1,000) 2013-2014

info.x_axis_title_reg: Public School Children (5-14 Yrs Old) with Asthma
info.y_axis_title_reg: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home
info.info_name: Public School Children (5-14 Yrs Old) with Asthma
info.info_how_calculated: Number of public school children, aged 5-14 years, with a diagnosis of asthma that has been reported to NYC DOHMH during the current or previous school year, divided by the 5-14 year old population, expressed per 1,000. Rates are calculated by residence of the child. Note: Use of a denominator consisting of all 5-14 year olds results in an underestimate of the true asthma prevalence, since the numerator represents only children enrolled in public schools that report to NYC DOHMH.
info.info_source: New York City Automated School Health Records

info.x_axis_title_reg: Public School Children (5-14 Yrs Old) with Persistent Asthma
info.y_axis_title_reg: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home
info.info_name: Public School Children (5-14 Yrs Old) with Persistent Asthma
info.info_how_calculated: Number of public school children, aged 5-14 years, with a most recent asthma diagnosis reported to NYC DOHMH from the previous or current school year that describes symptoms occurring more than twice per week, divided by the 5-14 year old population, expressed per 1,000. Rates are calculated by residence of the child. Note: Use of a denominator consisting of all 5-14 year olds results in an underestimate of the true asthma prevalence, since the numerator represents only children enrolled in public schools that report to NYC DOHMH.
info.info_source: New York City Automated School Health Records

Compare.compare_type: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 17 Yrs Old) (Estimated Annual Rate)
Compare.graph_title: Neighborhood Asthma triggers: Children ages 5 to 17 by Adults reporting secondhand smoke at home
Compare.y_axis_title: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home - Percent 2012
Compare.x_axis_title: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 17 Yrs Old) - Estimated Annual Rate (per 10,000 residents) 2012

info.y_axis_title_reg: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home
info.info_name: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 17 Yrs Old)
info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 17 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 17 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

 A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

info.x_axis_title_reg: Asthma Emergency Department Visits (Children 0 to 4 Yrs Old)
info.y_axis_title_reg: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home
info.info_name: Asthma Emergency Department Visits (Children 0 to 4 Yrs Old)
info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children up to 4 years old, divided by the population of children up to 4 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department.

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

info.info_name: Asthma Emergency Department Visits (Children 5 to 17 Yrs Old)
info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children aged 5 to 17 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 17 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department.

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Compare.graph_title: Neighborhood Asthma triggers: Adults by Adults reporting secondhand smoke at home
Compare.y_axis_title: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home - Percent 2012
Compare.x_axis_title: Asthma Emergency Department Visits (Adults) - Age-Adjusted Rate (per 10,000 residents) 2012

info.y_axis_title_reg: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home
info.info_name: Asthma Emergency Department Visits (Adults)
info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC adults (18 years and older), divided by the population in 5 year age groups, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department.

 

 An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown for adults, because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

info.info_name: Asthma Hospitalizations (Adults)
info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident adults (18 years and older), divided by the population in 5 year age groups, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown for adults, because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

info.info_how_calculated: Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who reported medically diagnosed asthma with symptoms in the last 12 months, divided by all adults and adjusted for age; expressed as percent.
